TRUE

`r chunk_reveal("str")`


```{r str, include=F}
str(3)

str("hello")

str(1.1)

str(1:8)

str(2L)

str(c(2, 5, 8))

```



---

`r chunk_reveal("mat")`

```{r mat, include=F}
matrix(1:10, nrow = 5)

matrix(1:10, ncol = 3)






matrix(c(1,2,3,4), 
       nrow = 2) * 2




(matrix(c(1,2,3,4), 
        nrow = 2) *
    matrix(c(1,2,3,4), 
       nrow = 2) )
(matrix(c(1,2,3,4), 
       nrow = 2) %*%
    matrix(c(1,2,3,4), 
       nrow = 2) )
```

# constructing data in r

---

`r chunk_reveal("dat")`

```{r dat, include=F}
data.frame(id = 1:6, 
           greet = c("hi", "bye", 
                     "hello", "chao",
                     "adios", "tchuss"),
           nums = c(2.3, 4.1, 3.5, 
                    3.2, 5.6, 8.9))

library(tibble) # also a part of the tidyverse
# tribble helps build small data sets
tribble(
  ~"id", ~"greet", ~"nums", # column heads
  1,        "hi",       2.3, 
  2,        "bye",      3.5,
  3,        "adios",    4.2
  )
```




---

`r chunk_reveal("fun")`

```{r fun, include=F}
mean(1:5)

mean(1:100^2)

sd(1:10)

mean(c(1, 4, 6, 7))

mean(c(1, 4, 6, 7, NA))

mean(c(1, 4, 6, 7, NA), na.rm = T)

sd(c(1:10, NA))

sd(c(1:10, NA), na.rm = T)
```


---

`r chunk_reveal("assign")`

```{r assign, include=F}
1:10 ->
  x

x * 5
x^2

rep(3, 10) ->
  y 

x + y ->
  z

5 -> 
  x

4 ->
  y

x + y ->
  z_1

z; z_1 # print both objects z and z_1
```


---

Some functions all about type...


---


`r chunk_reveal("is_type")`

```{r is_type, include=F}
is.character("hi")

is.numeric(1)

is.integer(2.3)

is.double(4L)

is.integer(4)

is.integer(4L)

is.factor("good")
```

---

`r chunk_reveal("as_type")`

```{r as_type, include=F}
as.numeric("hi")

as.integer(1)

as.character(2.3)

as.double(4L)

is.integer(4)

is.integer(4L)

as.factor(c("good", "bad"))

matrix(1:4, nrow = 2) %>% # this is a pipe operator
 # passes all of what procedes to function that follows
  as.vector()
```


---

`r chunk_reveal("factors")`

```{r factors, include=F}
c("50", "80") %>% 
  as.factor() %>% 
  as.numeric() # maybe surprising

c("50", "80") %>% 
  as.factor() %>% 
  as.character() %>% 
  as.numeric() # less surprising
```
